content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Find a one-way business class flight from Buenos Aires to Amsterdam on March 10, 2024, and provide the details of the flight with the shortest duration.  Please interact with https://www.google.com/travel/flights/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to set the departure city to Buenos Aires, replacing "Toronto". The correct textbox for the departure city is labeled [13].
Action: Type [13]; Buenos Aires
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current departure city is "Toronto." I need to delete this and input "Buenos Aires" into the same textbox to proceed with the correct departure city for the flight search.
Action: Type [13]; Buenos Aires
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.18
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: "Buenos Aires" is now set as the departure city. Next, I need to enter "Amsterdam" as the destination city into the "Where to?" field, which is labeled [14].
Action: Type [14]; Amsterdam
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The destination is now set to Amsterdam, and flight options from Buenos Aires to Amsterdam are visible. Next, I need to select the departure date, which currently appears incorrectly as Nov 20–27. I need to set it to March 10, 2024. The button for changing the date is not directly seen but is typically adjacent to the route/search bar. Based on the previous screenshots, the date input is [15].
Action: Click [15]
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The displayed dates are still incorrect (Nov 20–27); I need to locate the date selector and change it to March 10, 2024. The clickable element for date selection is not directly labeled but is part of the header "Thu, Nov 20 – Thu, Nov 27." This area is indicated at the top near the Amsterdam destination image, but there is no explicit label in the provided tags. Since no better tag matches the calendar directly, I'll try clicking the most likely header/date display area that changes dates.
Action: Click [13]
Confidence: 0.8
Completion: 0.38
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The page remains on the main results for flights from Buenos Aires to Amsterdam. The flights shown have round-trip pricing and durations. The visible durations are 21 hr 15 min, 16 hr 15 min, and 16 hr 45 min. However, I need to set the correct date (March 10, 2024) and filter for "one-way" and "business class," as the current results do not reflect these requirements. There is still no clear calendar control, but "More details" [15] might open options to change trip type and class.
Action: Click [15]
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.40
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The interface remains unchanged from the previous step. The calendar/date and trip/class setting options still do not appear. I may have clicked an element that does not bring up the controls. The area showing “Thu, Nov 20 – Thu, Nov 27” directly under "Amsterdam" is visually distinct and could be clickable or act as the entry for date changes, but it does not have a numeric label provided. The next step is to try a different approach, such as clicking the "Flights" tab [4], which may refresh the interface to show flight search filters prominently including date/trip/class options.
Action: Click [4]
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.42
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The flight search options are now clearly visible at the top, including setting trip type, number of passengers, class, departure, and return date. To proceed with the task requirements, I need to switch from "Round trip" to "One way" by clicking the "Round trip" dropdown [12]. This will allow me to specify a one-way flight.
Action: Click [12]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.50
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown for flight class is open, showing options like Economy, Premium economy, Business, and First. To fulfill the requirement for a business class flight, I need to select "Business" [15].
Action: Click [15]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.60
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The flight class is now set to Business. Currently, the search displays round trip flights, but I need a one-way ticket. The "Round trip" button [10] is still set and needs to be changed to "One way."
Action: Click [10]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.68
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The trip type dropdown is now open, showing options for "Round trip", "One way", and "Multi-city." To meet the requirement of booking a one-way flight, I should select "One way" [12].
Action: Click [12]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.75
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The ticket type is now set to "One way." However, the departure date is still set to "Mon, Nov 17" and should be changed to "March 10, 2024" as required by the task. The date input box is labeled [16].
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.80

Thought: The currently visible months are November and December, but I need to select March 10, 2024. I should click "Next" [77] repeatedly until I reach March 2024 in the calendar.
Action: Click [77]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.83

Thought: The calendar has advanced too far into late 2025 and January 2026, but I need to select March 2024. I should click "Previous" [77] repeatedly until I reach March 2024 in the calendar view.
Action: Click [77]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.84

Thought: The calendar has returned to November and December, but March 2024 is still not visible. I need to continue clicking "Previous" [76] several more times to reach March 2024.
Action: Click [76]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.85
